review.title: Generalized Online Transfer Learning for Climate Control in Residential Buildings
review.abstract: This paper presents an online transfer learning framework for improving temperature predictions in residential buildings. In transfer learning, prediction models trained under a set of available data from a target domain (e.g., house with limited data) can be improved through the use of data generated from similar source domains (e.g., houses with rich data). Given also the need for prediction models that can be trained online (e.g., as part of a model-predictive-control implementation), this paper introduces the generalized online transfer learning algorithm (GOTL). It employs a weighted combination of the available predictors (i.e., the target and source predictors) and guarantees convergence to the best weighted predictor. Furthermore, the use of Transfer Component Analysis (TCA) allows for using more than a single source domains, since it may facilitate the fit of a single model on more than one source domains (houses). This allows GOTL to transfer knowledge from more than one source domains. We further validate our results through experiments in climate control for residential buildings and show that GOTL may lead to non-negligible energy savings for given comfort levels.

metadata.title: Generalized Online Transfer Learning for Climate Control in Residential BuildingsI,II

sections.text: This paper presents an online transfer learning framework for improving temperature predictions in residential buildings. In transfer learning, prediction models trained on a range of available data from a target domain (e.g. house with limited data) can be improved by using data from similar source domains (e.g. houses with rich data). Given the need for prediction models that can be trained online (e.g. as part of an implementation of model prediction control), this work introduces the general online transfer learning algorithm (GOTL). It uses a weighted combination of available predictors (i.e. the target and the source predictors) and guarantees convergence with the best-weighted predictor. In addition, the use of transfer component analysis (TCA) allows the use of more than a single source domain as it can facilitate the adaptation of a single model to more than one source domain (e.g. the target and the source predictors).

sections.heading: 4.2. GOTL under multiple source domains
sections.text: In general, GOTL can be applied to multiple source domains following the same outline as described in Section 3.1. The only difference is the use of fS (·). In the case of a source house fS (·) = hS (·), where hS (·) is a supervised predictive function. In the case of multiple source domains fS (·) = hS (θ (·)), where θ (·) = WT [φ (·) Tφ (xj)] j оN.

sections.heading: 5. Experimental Setup
sections.text: In this section we describe the experimental setup with which the proposed GOTL algorithm for air conditioning of residential buildings was tested.

sections.heading: 5.1. Simulation platform
sections.text: We used a standard tool developed by the US Department of Energy for modeling and simulation of residential buildings, EnergyPlus (V7-2-0) [31]. The Building Controls Virtual Test Bed (BCVTB) simulation tool was also used to implement the data acquisition and climate control developed in MATLAB during runtime. A three-storey apartment building was modeled and simulated using the EnergyPlus environment to collect data from a realistic residential environment.

sections.heading: 5.2. Data Generation
sections.text: The simulated house is equipped with a radiant heat system that operates under an intermittent operating pattern (i.e., on / off). We deal with the prediction and control of the temperature of a single thermal zone of this house. In evaluating the predictive accuracy of the developed prediction models, the data were generated under a standard hysterical regulator with a set temperature of 21 ° C and the sampling period Ts = 1 / 2h (cf., [5, Section 5.2]), which assumes normal operating conditions. Instead, if the developed (online) prediction model was also used to provide predictions under an MPC formulation, the training data were generated under the currently implemented MPC. The details of these experiments will be discussed in a forthcoming section (Section 6.3). Irrespective of the data generation process (offline or online), the temperature of the interval zone is measured.

sections.heading: 5.3. Parameter Setup
sections.text: For the formation of either the source predictor fS (·) or the target predictor fk (·) we use a linear transfer model with an output error model structure (cf., [26, section 3]). In particular, the function f of the prediction model (1) is defined as a linear transfer model of the third order of output and input / fault variables (i.e., '= 3).The output variable is the temperature of the investigated thermal zone, while the input / fault variables include the water flow, the input temperature, the temperature of the adjacent zone (including the outside temperature) and the exogenous heat disturbances. Since we want to evaluate the performance of the combined predictor above the temperature of a thermal zone, perfect estimates are assumed for all input and exogenous disturbances.

sections.heading: 6. Experiments
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 6.1. Knowledge transfer with a single source house
sections.text: We demonstrate the performance of GOTL by conducting three experiments. As the number of experiments increases, the target house is increasingly chosen differently from the source house. Table 2 describes the similarities between the source house and the different target houses. Weather data were collected from Washington, DC, (source house) and from Linz, Austria, (target house) from November to March 2009. In Experiment 3, the target house also has different presence patterns. Presence patterns differ in the definition of the number of people of a certain age and gender, as well as their activities (for further details see [6]). The results of the experiments in Table 2 are presented in Figure 1 (Experiment 1), Figure 2 (Experiment 2) and Figure 3 (Experiment 3).

sections.heading: 6.2. Knowledge transfer with multiple source houses using TCA
sections.text: We show that data from multiple source houses can be combined with the domain generalization method TCA and the forecasting accuracy can be improved - compared to using only one source house. Furthermore, the combined source house predictor can be combined with the target house regressor using GOTL.For our evaluation, we use 2 source houses. Weather data from both source houses come from Washington, D.C. Source house regressor 2 is three times the size of source house regressor 1. The target house used is twice the size of source house regressor 1 and uses weather data from Linz, Austria. All three houses allow for a different presence pattern. The results are shown in Figure 4. It can be observed that the combined source house regressor is much better than the use of one of the source house regressor houses alone. One reason for the good source house performance is that the coefficients for the source house regressor the target house 3 are better than the comparable source house or shelf house paragraph 3.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions & Future Work
sections.text: We introduced the online transfer learning system GOTL, which is applicable for classification and regression tasks and makes it possible to optimally combine an (offline) source domain predictor with an online target domain predictor. Results showed the benefit of the combined predictor for significantly improving the prediction accuracy in the first weeks and months of a new building - compared to the sole use of the source house or target house predictor. Further improvements in prediction accuracy can be achieved by facilitating multiple source houses and TCA. Improvements in prediction accuracy also lead to significant energy savings with given comfort. Also important is the adaptive response of the proposed online transfer learning algorithm. Although the above experiments were evaluated over a period of five winter months, training an online regressor over longer periods of time can be challenging. This is primarily due to changes in weather conditions or heating behavior of a predisposition in such a GOL.

metadata.abstractText: This paper presents an online transfer learning framework for improving temperature predictions in residential buildings. In transfer learning, prediction models trained under a set of available data from a target domain (e.g., house with limited data) can be improved through the use of data generated from similar source domains (e.g., houses with rich data). Given also the need for prediction models that can be trained online (e.g., as part of a model-predictive-control implementation), this paper introduces the generalized online transfer learning algorithm (GOTL). It employs a weighted combination of the available predictors (i.e., the target and source predictors) and guarantees convergence to the best weighted predictor. Furthermore, the use of Transfer Component Analysis (TCA) allows for using more than a single source domains, since it may facilitate the fit of a single model on more than one source domains (houses). This allows GOTL to transfer knowledge from more than one source domains. We further validate our results through experiments in climate control for residential buildings and show that GOTL may lead to non-negligible energy savings for given comfort levels.
